posts.name: Rishab Tirupathi
posts.cooked:
We have connected our REV Throughbore encoder to our Teensy 4.0 microcontroller. We have used this datasheet to figure out how to ABI interface works, and have used the attachInterrupt Arduino function to be able to read the ABI input protocol.

However, this only gives us relative (incremental) positions. One thing that can be used to get the absolute position, is PWM . REV sells this adapter , which basically splits the yellow, blue, white, and green wires apart.

However, this alone does not explain how PWM output is enabled on the REV Througbore encoder. I wrote a program to log the outputs of the 4 wires (they are all set to OUTPUT mode). If we put the switch on A (ABI), then we get our ABI signal from the 4 wires (which resembles a quadrature encoder signal, although slightly different). If we put the switch on S (SPI/SSI), then we don’t get much output, since we need to set the clock and MOSI pins to INPUT to enable SPI. Neither of these scenarios gives us PWM absolute output from the encoder.

It would be easier to figure out how to enable PWM if REV provided schematics for how they wired the 6 pins of their encoder to the enclosed AEAT-8800-Q24 chip, but unfortunately, they do not. However, we know there has to be a way to enable PWM , we just don’t know how. Any help with this would be appreciated, as it would allow us to use our encoder (which we are putting on our elevator) as an absolute one.

link_counts.title: JST PH 6-pin to 4 Channel PWM Cable - 1m - REV Robotics
Is there a reliable way to get the total rotations of an encoder?

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
The PWM output is just the signal from the white wire.

That page also has the docs on what the PWM signal looks like.

Note, that the roboRIO can read this signal as well, with either the DutyCycle or DutyCycleEncoder classes. So it doesn’t have to be ran from a Teensy.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked:
Thad_House:

The PWM output is just the signal from the white wire.

Only in abi mode though, I had a silly experience not realizing it was acting as MISO

posts.name: Rishab Tirupathi
posts.cooked: Thank you for your feedback. I am not currently in the shop, so I tested this with my Teensy 4.0 by using the pulseIn() function to measure the width of the high pulse. However, it seems that this pulse goes from 0 to around 1030 microseconds, the goes back to 0 again when the sensor is rotated. This “reset” happens every full turn, meaning that the PWM for me is still pretty much relative, not absolute. I am wondering if maybe there is some precision lost when using pulseIn() , and if that precision would show more information (like how many rotations from the zero position the encoder has underwent).

posts.name: Rishab Tirupathi
posts.cooked:
By the way, I need to ask a clarifying question: Is the “zero point” on the encoder a specific place on the thing that rotates that you go past every turn, or is it a specific rotation that you go farther and farther from every turn? As in, if we turn our encoder off, rotate the wheel inside 360 degrees, and turn it back on, is there way to know that the wheel rotated 360 degrees?

This is important, because we are connecting the throughbore encoder to our elevator, and this event might happen on the elevator (if there is any electrical problem)

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
Thats what an absolute sensor does. It doesn’t detect rollovers, it instead just gives the absolute position in a single rotation of the sensor.

For the 2nd question, no there is no way to detect that the wheel rotated 360 degrees. The sensor only gives the absolute position of a single rotation.

Relative encoders (Like the quadrature output), don’t store any state of the sensor. It’s up to the device to track how many ticks have occured to know how much the sensor has moved. Whereas for the absolute sensor, you will always know where you are in a single rotation, even if the sensor reboots.

Neither of them however would be able to track more than a rotation while powered off.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: If you do need to detect multiple rotations, you can use a gear ratio of n:1 between the measured shaft and the encoder where n is the number of rotations you need to measure, but you will get 1/n the precision.

posts.name: Rishab Tirupathi
posts.cooked: Thank you both for your feedback! We will be able to use it well.
